note.p: Death: Chateau Villeneuve-l'Etang, near Paris, France (28 September 1895)
Research Field: Crystallography, chemistry, microbiology, immunology
Education: Arbois; Besancon; Ecole Normale, Paris

Career: Professor of Physics, Lycee, Dijon (1848); Professor of Chemistry, Strasbourg (1852); carried out fundamental work on fermentations (1850s-1870s); studied infectious diseases (from 1877); Pasteur Institute, Paris, was founded in his honour (1888)
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc 1897-1898 vol 62 pp xliii-lix signed by P F F
References: Sir Ashley Miles, 'Reports by Louis Pasteur and Claude Bernard on the Organization of Scientific Teaching and Research' in NR 1982-83 vol 37 pp 101-118
B Heap, 'From the dust of the Earth? Things come to life: spontaneous generation revisited by Henry Harris' in NR 2003 vol 57 pp 107-108
H Gest, 'The Discovery of Microorganisms by Robert Hooke and Antoni von Leeuwenhoek, Fellows of the Royal Society' in NR 2004 vol 58 pp 187-201
Anne Cooke, 'From Microbes to Man. Ulf Lagerkvist, Pioneers of microbiology and the Nobel Prize' in NR 2004 vol 58 pp 234-236
